messages.subject: cartoon network
messages.msgSnippet: ... and said the way in which some of the characters talked to eachother showed alot of rudeness although I have not seen that one.
messages.messageBody:
>>>>>>>>>My dh watched Ed, Ed, Eddy with him
and said the way in which some of the characters talked to eachother
showed alot of rudeness although I have not seen that one.<<<<<<<<



I'll put in my vote against Ed, Edd and Eddy! But even I have to agree that
it IS sometimes pretty funny. At the LEAST, they prompt discussions on the
situations and reactions----and that large vocabulary! Now, Cow and Chicken?
well, I STILL haven't found anything redeeming about THAT one! <G> But Duncan
gutgiggles all through it----so at least HE finds it entertaining! THAT's the
redeeming quality!



>>>>The
fairly oddparents really gets under my skin and that one we do not
allow because I think he is too young.<<<<


Now, *I* happen to LIKE Fairly Oddparents! <G> Go figure! I like The Rugrats,
too, but am in the minority there!


>>>> IS he making an
intelligent choice or just staring like a dog foaming at the mouth
watching shows that corporate america has put out there marketed to
little boys (harsh but how I feel. At this point I feel the only
reason he is watching is because it is on cartoon network. I have
tried to discuss that just because it is on that channel does not
mean it is a good choice.<<<<<<



Well first off, the words "intelligent choice" kind of makes me feel icky.
It's just a choice. Is there NOTHING better on? To HIM? Then he's making a
choice that's important to him at the time. Duncan did the cartoonnetwork ONLY
for a couple of years, so I've been there. He's seven now----and his choices
are becoming more "refined" and more "mature"----but I wouldn't say they're
necessarily more (or less) "intelligent". There's *something* he's getting out of
Cartoon Network that YOU're not seeing. And he's not the only one!



>>>> I am struggling with balancing that with
giving hime the freedom to make his own choices. <<<<


Give him the choices NOW, and you won't be worrying so much about his future.
MAKE his choices now FOR him, and HE'll be worrying in the future.

~Kelly


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
